title: R41233
content: Most of the funding for HUD comes from discretionary appropriations provided by Congress. Programs focus on housing issues for low-income households, including rental assistance for the poor, elderly, and disabled. Public Housing, Section 8 Vouchers, and Section 8 project-based rental assistance are the main programs. HOME and Community Development Block Grants are also important block grant programs. HUD receives funding from Congress for housing programs, including rental assistance for low-income households. Two block grant programs, HOME and Community Development Block Grants, help finance housing and community development activities for low-income families. Other grant programs assist homeless individuals, including those with AIDS. FHA insures mortgages for lower-income home buyers and developers of affordable rental buildings. FHA fees sustain the insurance fund and cover administrative costs. Surplus funds have been used for various purposes. The HUD budget has received emergency supplemental funding in recent years, including $20 billion for recovery assistance after Hurricane Katrina. The economic stimulus legislation provided over $13 billion to HUD's programs. Total enacted appropriations for HUD have increased by 57% in the past nine years. Total enacted appropriations for HUD, including emergency supplemental funding, have increased by 57% in the past nine years. The rate of growth has been on the rise in recent years, with year-over-year increases of 5% or more each year, peaking at nearly 12% in FY2010. Adjusting for inflation, the "real" funding growth has been less robust, with a 17% increase over the same period. HUD's funding growth has been increasing in recent years, with most of the growth occurring in the last two years. The components of HUD's annual funding include regular annual appropriations, emergency appropriations, rescissions, and offsets, with programs funded mainly through discretionary appropriations. Congress determines the amount of funding obligated for HUD's programs and activities each year. Congress provides funding for HUD's programs through regular annual appropriations and emergency appropriations, often in response to disasters. Emergency funds are typically provided outside of regular appropriations acts, in addition to annual appropriations. Congressional appropriators are limited in the amount of new discretionary funding they can provide each year, leading them to either reduce regular appropriations or find offsets. The cost of HUD's regular annual appropriations acts is offset through rescissions and offsetting receipts and collections. The total net budget authority for HUD is determined by the interaction between new appropriations and offsets. Net budget authority is the estimated cost of the HUD budget provided each year. The net budget authority provided to HUD each year is not the best measure of funding for its programs. Despite a 57% increase in net non-emergency budget authority from FY2002 to FY2010, there are important trends masked by this overall increase. The 57% increase in net non-emergency budget authority from FY2002 to FY2010 is not solely due to increased appropriations for HUD programs. Regular annual appropriations grew by only 37%, while offsetting receipts and collections declined significantly. This resulted in a partial increase in net non-emergency budget authority during this period. During FY2002-FY2010, the 37% growth in regular appropriations was mainly due to the expansion of HUD's Section 8 voucher and project-based rental assistance programs, which are the largest components of the HUD budget. Appropriations for the Section 8 programs increased by over 70%, while funding for other HUD programs only grew by 8% during this period. During FY2002-FY2010, Section 8 programs accounted for a significant portion of HUD's regular appropriations, increasing from 46% to 57%. While Section 8 funding grew, funding for other HUD programs declined. However, in FY2009 and FY2010, funding for other HUD programs began to grow as well. The decline in offsetting receipts was mainly due to decreases in receipts from FHA mortgage insurance programs. The offsetting receipts available from FHA to offset the cost of new HUD appropriations declined significantly from FY2004 to FY2010. The annual appropriations process starts with the President's budget request, followed by hearings and crafting of appropriations legislation by the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. Legislation must be enacted before September 30 to avoid a government funding lapse. The FY2011 appropriations process for HUD began with the President's budget release in February 2010 and ended with the signing of P.L. 112-10 in April 2011. Congress enacts short-term continuing resolutions to continue funding at prior levels until final actions are taken. The process spanned two calendar years and two Congresses. The President's FY2011 budget requested about $45.6 billion in net new budget authority for HUD, a 1% decrease from FY2010. However, this decrease would actually result in a 3% increase in appropriations for HUD programs overall. The budget proposed offsetting the increase with a substantial rise in offsetting collections from changes to FHA mortgage insurance programs. The President's FY2011 budget requested funding increases for Section 8 programs, homeless programs, and HUD's research needs. Decreased funding was requested for programs for the elderly, persons with disabilities, and public housing repairs. No new funding was requested for the brownfields redevelopment program. The House approved the FY2011 HUD funding bill on July 29. The FY2011 HUD funding bill approved by the House on July 29, 2010 (H.R. 5850) would have provided about $1 billion more for HUD than requested by the President. The bill rejected proposed cuts to housing programs for the elderly and persons with disabilities, public housing capital funding, and the brownfields program. It also rejected funding for initiatives like Choice Neighborhoods and Transforming Rental Assistance. The bill was not enacted. The Senate bill, like the House bill, would have provided about $1 billion more for HUD than requested by the President. It included a 1% increase in net new budget authority and a 5% increase in appropriations for HUD programs. The Senate bill also rejected proposed cuts to housing programs for the elderly and persons with disabilities, as well as public housing capital funding. The Senate committee bill, unlike the House bill, would have funded the President's Choice Neighborhoods Initiative and other programs for the elderly, persons with disabilities, and public housing capital funding. The bill was not enacted before the end of the 111th Congress, leading to a series of continuing resolutions to maintain funding at FY2010 levels. The first continuing resolution in the federal budget for HUD's accounts lasted from October 1, 2010, until December 3, 2010. Subsequent CRs extended the original one through December 18, 2010, and December 21, 2010. The last CR approved before the end of the 111th Congress was set to expire on March 4, 2011, leaving funding decisions for the remainder of FY2011 to the 112th Congress. This CR also extended FHA mortgage limit increases through the end of FY2011. The House approved a year-long continuing resolution, H.R. 1, to fund the federal government through the end of FY2011. This bill would have provided about $5 billion less in aggregate appropriations for HUD programs compared to FY2010. The Senate failed to pass H.R. 1 and a Senate Amendment that would have increased funding for HUD by nearly $6 billion without rescinding any FY2010 funding. It would have reduced net budget authority from FY2010 by over $1 billion (under 3%) but increased by about $900 million. The 112th Congress approved a short-term CR (H.J.Res. 44, P.L. 112-4) to fund the government through March 18, 2011, maintaining most accounts at FY2010 levels but reducing funding for some accounts. The Community Development Fund (CDF) account, which funds the Community Development Block Grant (CDBG) program, was reduced by approximately $195 million under H.J.Res. 44. This reduction eliminated funding for congressional earmarks through Economic Development Initiatives (EDI) and Neighborhood Initiatives (NI) in FY2010. Congress then passed another short-term CR (H.J.Res. 48, P.L. 112-6) to continue funding through April 8, 2011, maintaining most HUD accounts at FY2010 levels but continuing the reduction in funding for the CDF. H.J.Res. 48 provided no funding for HUD's Brownfields Redevelopment account, which had been funded at $17 million in FY2010. A final short-term CR, P.L. 112-8, extended funding through April 15, 2011, while work on a final FY2011 year-long funding bill was completed. It reduced funding for the public housing operating fund and specified that no CDF funds could be used for EDI and NI earmarks. On April 15, 2011, the Department of Defense and Full-Year Continuing Appropriations Act of 2011 (P.L. 112-10) was signed into law, providing year-long FY2011 appropriations. The Department of Defense and Full-Year Continuing Appropriations Act of 2011 (P.L. 112-10) provided year-long FY2011 appropriations for HUD and other government agencies. It funded some HUD programs at FY2010 levels, reduced funding for some programs, and increased funding for Section 8 programs. The law included an across-the-board 0.2% rescission from non-defense discretionary accounts, resulting in a decrease of about 11% in net new budget authority for HUD. The FY2011 appropriations for HUD under the Department of Defense and Full-Year Continuing Appropriations Act of 2011 reduced funding for some programs and increased funding for Section 8 programs. There was an 11% decrease in net new budget authority for HUD due to a 0.2% rescission from non-defense discretionary accounts. The requested decrease in net new budget authority would only represent a 4% decrease in appropriations for HUD programs in aggregate, with a substantial increase in offsetting collections and receipts from the FHA mortgage insurance programs. The FHA insures mortgage loans to make credit more widely available at a lower cost. The FHA home loan insurance programs, administered through two program accounts in the HUD budget, make credit more widely available at a lower cost. The Mutual Mortgage Insurance (MMI) Fund is the largest of the FHA insurance funds, focusing on single-family home loans. The Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008 also impacted the Home Equity Conversion Mortgage. The Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008 (P.L. 110-289) moved the FHA's reverse mortgage program into the MMI Fund, creating two risk categories: MMI Purchase and Refinance, and MMI HECM. The MMI Fund provides insurance for single-family loans, while the GI/SRI Fund covers riskier mortgages and special-purpose loans. The Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990 (FCRA) determines the cost of federal loan insurance in a fiscal year based on the net present value of expected cash flows from insured loans. Cash inflows come from insurance premiums, while outflows are for payments to lenders for loan defaults. The subsidy rate is the net value of these cash flows as a percentage of insured loan volume. The subsidy rate is calculated based on the net present value of cash flows from insured loans, expressed as a percentage of loan volume. It is shown as a negative number if cash inflows exceed outflows, and as a positive number if outflows exceed inflows. This rate determines the credit subsidy needed for federal credit programs over the life of the loans. Actual cash flows may differ from the projected subsidy amount. The MMI Fund historically has a negative subsidy rate, generating money for the government by making more in fees than paying out in claims. This has allowed the fund to operate without needing an appropriation from Congress. The MMI Fund historically operates without needing Congress's appropriation, generating money through fees. It is divided into two risk categories: Purchase and Refinance, and HECM. The Purchase and Refinance category is estimated to have a negative subsidy rate of -2.59% for FY2011, generating $5.8 billion in negative credit subsidy. The MMI Fund is projected to have a negative credit subsidy of $5.8 billion in FY2011, partly due to proposed FHA reforms. The Congressional Budget Office estimates a smaller negative credit subsidy of around $1.9 billion for the Purchase and Refinance risk category. The Congressional Budget Office projected a negative credit subsidy of around $1.9 billion for the MMI Fund in FY2011, with $960 million without FHA's proposed changes and an additional $902 million with HUD-proposed program reforms. Despite differences with the Administration's projections, CBO anticipated this category of the MMI Fund to generate more revenue than losses in the upcoming year, eliminating the need for a positive credit subsidy in FY2011. FHA's estimates of negative credit subsidy for FY2011 were revised upward after the full-year appropriations law was enacted in April 2011. In 2011, FHA's estimates of FY2011 negative credit subsidy were revised upward due to an increase in the annual premium charged by FHA. The change resulted in a -3.92% subsidy rate for the Mutual Mortgage Insurance Fund's Purchase and Refinance risk category for FY2011. FHA's estimates of offsetting receipts for this category in FY2011 increased to nearly $10 billion by the time the FY2012 budget was enacted. The refinance risk category in FY2011 increased to nearly $10 billion by the time the FY2012 budget was released, from an estimate of $5.8 billion when the FY2011 budget was released. CBO also increased its estimate of FHA receipts for FY2011 by over $1 billion. The Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008 moved the Home Equity Conversion Mortgage program into the MMI fund separately. The MMI HECM risk category is estimated to have a positive credit subsidy of 0.83%. In FY2011, HUD proposed changes to the HECM program to reduce the need for positive credit subsidies. This included increasing borrowers' annual insurance premiums and adjusting the formula for initial loan sizes. These changes aimed to decrease the need for a $250 million positive credit subsidy. The FY2012 appropriations law aimed to reduce the need for credit subsidies for HECMs by making adjustments to the program to result in a zero credit subsidy. This was in response to the increasing demand for FHA-insured mortgages due to tightening lending standards in the private market. The demand for FHA-insured mortgages has been increasing in recent years, with FHA insuring 18.7% of new single-family mortgages in FY2009, up from about 2% in FY2006. The average credit score on FHA-insured loans has improved to the 690s, indicating better credit quality. However, the default rate on past FHA-insured loans is still rising, putting strain on the MMI Fund. Congress addressed this issue in the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 (P.L. 101-508). The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 mandated that the MMI Fund must have a capital reserve ratio of at least 2% within 10 years. By FY2009, the capital reserve ratio was only 0.53%, the first time it fell below 2%. FHA announced measures to address concerns over the fund's financial stability. FHA has proposed changes to its single-family mortgage insurance programs, including increasing the annual mortgage insurance premium. Congressional action may be required for some changes. The Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 mandated a 2% capital reserve ratio for the MMI Fund, which fell below that in FY2009. After the Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1990 mandated a 2% capital reserve ratio for the MMI Fund, FHA increased annual mortgage insurance premiums for borrowers with downpayments of 5% or less. The premiums were raised to 1.15% of the loan balance for downpayments of 5% or less and 1.10% for downpayments greater than 5% starting on April 18, 2011. Congress also set a statutory cap on the upfront premium. FHA raised the upfront mortgage insurance premium to 2.25% for loans endorsed on or after April 5, 2010, but lowered it to 1% for loans endorsed on or after October 1, 2010, after P.L. 111-229 was enacted. FHA proposes changes to downpayment and credit score requirements, with borrowers between 500-579 needing a 10% downpayment and those with 580+ requiring 3.5%. Seller concessions may be reduced from 6% to 3%. FHA plans to reduce seller concessions to 3% from 6% and increase oversight of FHA-approved lenders, requiring Congress to grant authority for additional enforcement actions. The FHA Reform Act of 2010 (H.R. 5072) aimed to give FHA more authority to require lenders to indemnify for claims on non-compliant mortgages, terminate lenders with high default rates, and establish a Deputy Assistant Secretary for Risk Management. The FHA Reform Act of 2010 aimed to abolish the position of FHA chief risk officer and give FHA authority to contract with outside credit risk analysis sources. Authorized appropriations were provided for staff to review lender performance from FY2010 through FY2014. HUD provides capital grants and rental assistance through programs like Section 202 and Section 811 for elderly and disabled residents. In the Section 202 program, property owners may provide supportive services to residents, while in the Section 811 program, supportive services are mandatory. HUD has funded over 106,000 units of Section 202 housing and 30,000 units of Section 811 housing. The President proposed no new funding for these programs in FY2011 to allow for program redesign. The President's proposal would have reduced funding for Section 202 and Section 811 programs for low-income elderly residents. Section 202 and related programs would have been funded at $274 million, compared to $825 million in FY2010. The Section 811 program would have received $90 million in FY2011, compared to $300 million in FY2010. Neither the House-passed appropriations bill (H.R. 5850) nor the Senate committee-passed bill (S. 3644) followed the President's recommendations to redesign the programs or stop producing new units. Both H.R. 5850 and S. 3644 proposed maintaining funding levels for Section 202 at $825 million and for Section 811 at $300 million. The difference in funding levels was due to the treatment of Section 811 vouchers, with S. 3644 allocating $200 million. Both bills would have moved funding for Section 811 vouchers to the Section 8 tenant-based rental assistance account. In FY2011, nearly $114 million was allocated for voucher renewals. Congress appropriated $400 million for Section 202 programs and $150 million for Section 811 programs. Funding for Section 811 vouchers was split between Section 811 and Section 8 tenant-based accounts, with "up to" $32 million for Section 811 renewals. In FY2011, $67 million was allocated for Section 811 voucher renewals, $20 million less than in FY2010. $89 million was provided for Service Coordinators and $39 million for the Assisted Living Conversion program within the Section 202 funds. The Section 8 Housing Choice Voucher program is funded through the tenant-based rental assistance account and is the largest assistance program administered by HUD. The rental assistance account is the largest program administered by HUD, funding vouchers for housing subsidies and administrative costs for PHAs. Funding comes from current year appropriations and advance appropriations for the following fiscal year. In FY2010, Congress allocated over $16 billion for voucher renewals to PHAs based on their prior year costs and utilization. The Senate bill for funding PHAs did not include reallocation authority requested by the President, citing concerns about potential cost increases. The committee report also directed HUD to improve monitoring of PHAs' financial management. No changes were made to the funding allocation formula from FY2010 in H.R. 1 or the final FY2011 appropriations law. The FY2011 appropriations law (P.L. 112-10) did not change the funding allocation formula from FY2010. Both the House and Senate bills allocated less for renewals than requested by the President but more than in FY2010. The President's budget requested funding for mainstream vouchers for persons with disabilities in the Section 8 account, with HUD requesting $114 million for this purpose. Both the House and Senate bills supported this request, but H.R. 1 did not explicitly include funding for tenant-based rental assistance. The final FY2011 appropriations law (P.L. 112-10) appropriated less than a third of the amount requested by the President for Section 811 renewals. Each Public Housing Authority (PHA) has a contract with HUD for authorized vouchers, totaling around 2.3 million vouchers. Congress can create additional vouchers in some years, increasing the total number available. In recent years, Congress has created additional vouchers, including replacement vouchers for families displaced from HUD programs and new incremental vouchers for special populations or purposes. For example, in FY2010, $15 million was allocated for child welfare system vouchers and $75 million for homeless veterans. In FY2011, $85 million was requested for new vouchers for supportive housing for at-risk families and individuals. The House and Senate bills from the 111th Congress included funding for homelessness programs, such as vouchers for homeless veterans and families displaced by hurricanes. The Senate bill also allocated funds for the Family Unification Program. The bill would have provided $16 million for the Family Unification Program (FUP), which offers vouchers to families in the child welfare system. H.R. 1 did not include funding for new vouchers, but the final FY2011 appropriations law (P.L. 112-10) allocated about $50 million for VASH vouchers. The project-based rental assistance account funds existing Section 8 rental assistance contracts between HUD and private property owners, providing subsidies to eligible low-income families. The program allowed tenants to live in subsidized units at 30% of their incomes with previously agreed-upon rent. Contracts funded by Congress for 20- to 40-year periods require new annual appropriations once expired. More appropriations are needed as contracts expire and owners choose to renew. Some contracts lack funding to finish terms, requiring new funding for completion. In FY2011, the President requested over $9 billion for project-based rental assistance, with $662 million needed for amendment funding. HUD aims to provide full-year funding for all contracts and renew expiring ones. Funding for the account has been a mix of current year and advance appropriations since FY2009. In FY2011, the President requested funding for project-based rental assistance. Both the House and Senate bills proposed to adopt the President's funding level, with some variations. President Obama's budget also included $350 million for a new "Transforming Rental Assistance" initiative. The "Transforming Rental Assistance" initiative aims to streamline HUD's rental assistance programs and increase residential mobility options for HUD-assisted tenants. It involves transferring HUD-assisted housing units to a new form of project-based rental assistance that allows families to take their subsidies with them if they choose to move. The President's budget aims to transfer 300,000 units of public and multifamily housing properties to a new form of project-based rental assistance, allowing tenants to take their subsidies with them if they choose to move. The initiative was not included in the final FY2011 appropriations law. Public housing program, established in 1937, provides rental units for low-income families, with Congress continuing to allocate funds despite no new developments in recent years. Despite no new developments in recent years, Congress continues to provide funds to over 3,100 Public Housing Authorities (PHAs) that own and maintain 1.2 million units. HUD offers operating funds to fill the gap between rent contributions and maintenance costs, as well as capital funds for large projects. The HOPE VI program supports the redevelopment of distressed public housing, focusing on creating mixed-income communities. The President's FY2011 budget requested increased funding for the Public Housing operating fund and decreased funding for the public housing capital fund. President Obama's FY2010 budget request included the Transformation Initiative to strengthen HUD's research and technological capacities. The fund may be used for research, evaluation, program demonstrations, technical assistance, and information technology. Funding request involves appropriations for reducing mortgage fraud and authority for the Secretary to transfer up to 1% from HUD's budget to a transformation fund.
